overview_of_class: Much has been made of the hegemony of vision in the modern era, and certainly, for visual artists, questions about the nature of vision seem especially relevant. Drawing on thinkers from a variety of fields including the sciences, philosophy, psychoanalysis and the arts, this seminar will explore what it is to see, what it might mean to look, and what it might mean to be the object of a look rather than its originator. Multiple short texts will be discussed each week, including texts describing early theories of about about the mechanics of how we see along with current scientific insights; readings on the role of seeing in the creation of our sense of self, and the power dynamics implicit in looking and being looked at. Jean-Paul Sartre, Jaques Lacan, Kaja Silverman, Jeremy Bentham, Laura Mulvey, Frantz Fanon, Michel de Certeau, Michel Foucault, Silvan Tomkins, and Maurice Merleau-Ponty are just a few of the many authors we will touch on.
